this is a k-edge to gopro mount. with the mounting holes rotated 90 degrees. this would install under your k-edge mounted garmin or wahoo gps. the holes are rotated to allow the use of the 2 unused holes. the other 2 holes are used by the blue wahoo gps insert. it can fit a garmin based holder but the screws have to be very short. I have a similar mount on this site with the holes rotated 90 degrees opposite of this for garmin based mounts. requires 2 screws 3mx4 or 6 countersunk (4mm length has total length of 6mm, 6mm length has a total length of 8mm). it may be hard to get the correct length screws. that's why this is rotated to allow the use of the unused holes. the gopro tabs slightly overlap the screw holes. I haven't figured out how to remove that small amount of material. feel free to make any changes to the object.

DON'T CLICK THIS -> https://www.facebook.com/Jb-designs-155628831607396/

Instagram -> https://www.instagram.com/jsp_bv/

The purpose of this project is to design a food product that goes one step beyond the act of eating by introducing a function that is not typically associated to these daily moments. Besides attending the perception of the object, we have decided to include a recreational component to surpass the limits of what a meal is considered to be. As if we were in the middle of a seascape, we have decided to transform a bowl of soup into an ocean where three different designs of pasta fish, eel and octopus are not to be caught with classic utensils (e.g. spoons), but instead with other ones: a hook, a trident and a fishing net, in other to achieve different levels of difficult. To sum it up, this project tries to turn the process of eating into a game based on a simple score system (depending on the utensil and the animal fished you achieve different scores), while also keeping a poetic image of the food history.

This is the display case I came up with for my D-Bot build. It can be mounted pretty much anywhere on the V-Slot and can be rotated or tilted.

Update 5/21/2017
Cleaned everything up so it plays a little nicer with different slicers. The threads are different, so if you reprint the nut you will have to reprint the mount also. Please let me know if there are any problems...

Putting It Together

Place the retaining ring over the pivot ball.
Snap the ball into the nut.
Snap the retaining ring into the recess on the nut.
Use 2 3x8 screws and nuts to attach to the back of the case.
Thread onto the v-slot mount.
This was designed using Fusion 360.

remixed_from.author: SpannerHands
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal Improved High Flow Fan Blower Upgrade

title: Blower Fan duct for PrinterBot Simple Metal, vertical, more improvified

description.text:
Credit to SpannerHands for inspiration, and for his nozzle, which I have included here unaltered for convenience. (If you are looking at nozzle alternatives, you should read Desi Quintans nozzle study: http://www.desiquintans.com/coolingtests.)

However, I didn't care for the sideways mounting of the fan, so this duct moves it to a vertical and fore-and-aft position.

(Incidentally, I sliced this using pretty aggressive settings in Cura's Fuzzy Surface feature; that's why it looks... fuzzy... in the picture.)

ETA: In case your slicer doesn't have a "lay flat" tool, I've added a copy of the STL rotated into proper printing orientation.

ETA: I was experimenting with Sigsmond0's cable chain (thing:1060522), and the part E_motor_mount just barely clears the duct. I added a "more clearance" version to move the fan out a few millimeters. I have left the original, but recommend using this version, as there doesn't seem to be a downside.

remixed_from.author: Microdure
remixed_from.title: Adapter Flight controler Femto SP Racing F3 Emax STM32F303 F3

title: FT Gremlin Femto F3 Mount with Camera

description.text:
This is a nice, little, thin, lightweight and useful camera and flight controler mount for your FT Gremlin. The camera mount tilts the camera back at 10 degrees. The flight controller sits down nice and flat into it's mounting area with 2mm clearance underneath which is perfect to put a piece of double sided foam tape to hold the F3 down snug. This was specifically designed to work with TJ's designed frame but it may work with others as well. If so, leave a comment and I'll add to the description.

This mount is only 1mm thick at the mounting points so it slips easily under the stand-offs included with the Gremlin kits.

It was a tight fit getting the top plate under the cloverleaf antenna but it worked. A future design might raise the camera up a few millimeters to reduce this problem.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

After using my original 600TVL camera mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2300292), I quickly realized it would be nice to incorporate a sturdy an LEVEL place to mount the Gremlin's Femto F3 flight controller. I had been using just double-sided foam tape and the quad tended to drift a little and the flight controller always seemed to be tilted this way or that.

I found an printed Microdure's Femto F3 mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2041827) but again as I was installing it I realized how fiddly it was to have all these separate pieces. Thus I combine both and came up with this.

As Printed (with supports) Supports

Supports can be a pain to remove especially where they contact the actual part. Use care when removing because this is a very thin, light and flexible print.

Overall print time was just over 23 minutes.
Fusion 360 Finished product shown with the two original designs that inspired it.

comments.text: I printed two of these off.  The back plate is very thin and really needs to be beefed up.  One broke before I could even get it off the build plate.  The other is too weak to really be of much use and would not survive a crash.  Any way you can mod the back to be 2 or three layers thicker?

title: Angled adaptor for Oculus Rift sensor camera

description.text:
This adaptor screws onto a standard photography tripod, or onto the original rift sensor stand. It is designed to give the sensor more downwards coverage, for when the sensor is positioned in a high corner.

I implemented a "kink" or offset in an attempt to keep the correct center of gravity, but in retrospect, it really wouldn't have mattered - the sensors are quite light-weight.

EDIT: r4 (not depicted in photos) is a bit shorter (less offset), to compensate for cable weight.

See this for good roomscale setup tips:
https://www.oculus.com/blog/oculus-roomscale-tips-for-setting-up-a-killer-vr-room/

I use this app to visualise and tweak the sensor placement/coverage from within VR:
https://www.wearvr.com/apps/desk-scene-check-your-camera-bounds

title: Electron － Command Module for Proton & Neutron

description.text:
The Electron is a housing for the electronics, extruder motor, and filament of the Neutron and Proton, the open source 3D printers designed by Layer One, the creator of Atom 3D Printers.

Link to Proton: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149685
Link to Neutron: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149660

While the RepRap project produced some functional printers, it was clear that nobody had intended to produce something for the desktop of the discerning designer. That’s where Layer One’s Proton, Neutron, and now Electron come in. If you’re an open-source advocate, a tinkerer, and a designer with an eye for aesthetics, you’ll want one of these on your desk.

All the printed parts of Electron are right here. Electron was built in OnShape. Log in to remix your own version of it, it’s free as long as you share what you have made. Visit our website for the BOM, CAD files, assembly guide and everything else.

title: Open Alpha Headphones Bass Adjustable Ear Cups

description.text: This is a remix of the Open Alpha headpones given to the diy community by MrSpeakers Dan Clark. He designed the original as a production product. Later on he gifted the design to the community. My remix replaces the vent holes on the original with an adjustable vent. Just thread an M3 set screw into the hole on top and adjust them as desired. This is basically the same as his Alpha Prime design. I would start with M3x12 it can totally seal the vent and also leave it completely open, though a little of the screw will be sticking out the top of the cups when the vent is totally open. If you want to go totally open or close to it maybe an M3x10 or M3x8 would be a better choice. They use a Hirose connector, though there is a remix that uses a 2.5mm jack instead. The .iges file is included for editing and remixing. The baffles that go with these as well as the original cups are available here.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/kBsb0myyym3

You will need to print this on it's side so the hooks are strong enough to go inside the peg board. Use supports everywhere (not just touching build plate) so the hooks print properly

These magnetic pegboard mounts are meant to be used with plywood that has 1/4" holes in it. The pegs are 1" center to center, which is the spacing of most 1/4" pegboard. The magnets are 10mm dia x 3mm thick and there are 3 in each hole. The only thing to know here is that they need to be printed on their side so they're strong enough to go in the hole.

Please let me know if anyone ends up making this design. I'd be more than happy to hear from you.

Thanks for looking!

comments.text: Nice! I'm a little confused about the hole - if you print this on its side, does it need support IN the hole? If so, does that come out easily, and what settings (besides "support everywhere" as you mentioned) for support parameters , e.g. in Cura?

comments.text: Thanks! Support will be printed in the hole, however it should be really easy to remove. I use Simplify3D for my slicer with the default support settings. title: Monoprice Select Mini SD Card Extender Holder

description.text: I got sick of ferrying the micro SD card back and forth and having to keep track of the micro SD card adapter between prints so I designed this bracket to hold a micro SD card extender adapter cable.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175 to 0.306

Infill:

20

Installation

I designed this to work with on the left side of the printer which gives it more clearance, doesn't interfere with X gantry support systems, and allows for routing the ribbon cable through the machine. You can see in the pictures how I routed the cable beneath the side plate, which has enough clearance for the cable to still slide freely and not cause any damage. Uses existing screws.

Designed to work with: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01D9JIUU0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

When routing the ribbon cable be sure to give it 1 half turn so that the micro-SD adapter part comes out the other side upside down and is a simple, single turn into the port.

Note: If you'd like to install this piece on the opposite side mirror the part in your slicer, it is not symmetrical and there isn't enough clearance at the base of the printer if its not mirrored before printing.

comments.text:
Printed this today after getting the adapter/cable from Amazon, and it works great! I really love not having to deal with swapping the MicroSD in and out of the SD adapter for my computer, or dealing with the tiny slot on the side of the printer.
The cover seems to snap on perfectly tight, although I might look for some glue if it gets loose later on.
The only issue I had was for some reason the "Read Only" switch on my MicroSD-to-SD adapter kept getting flipped when I plugged it in to this. I just broke the switch off and now it works fine. :)

comments.text: Been using a wireless SD card with my Mini for about 6 months now, just slice and write the gcode file to a mapped drive on my Windows laptop that connects to a Toshiba FlashAir W-03 SD card. Be sure to get the W-03 card or newer, the cheaper W-02 won't work ...
comments.author: rjpost942

comments.text:
Anyone else having issues with their Micro-SD to SD converter?
If I remove the SD card and load files onto it and then put the SD card back into the reader, the printer says the SD card is empty.
If I turn off the printer and power it back on, Voila! It is now able to see the content of the SD card.
Seems kind of pointless if I have to reboot the printer every time I remove the card.
I also tried plugging/replugging the Micro-SD connector with and without the SD card in the slot of the adapter and the printer simply won't read the SD card unless I reboot the printer.
Thoughts? Experiences? Advice? Thanks!
comments.author: Mckitrick

comments.text: Mine has been super stable and I only get issues when I move my printer and knock out the microSD part.  I'd try and do a reformat of your SD card, otherwise (assuming your microSD slot never had issues before), your adapter could just not be working.  They're not very robust and assuming you got a similar one to mine, its cheaply made with cheap components so there will likely just always be a chance you could get a lemon.  I've been lucky but reading the Amazon reviews it doesn't sound like your experience is abnormal.
comments.author: Mckitrick

comments.text:
Hey you're online! :)
I bought two Micro-SD to SD adapters from Ali-Express and they both behave the same way.
The printer works perfectly with Micro-SD cards, so I know the port is fine. It's just annoying getting the Micro-SD card in and out and then doing it all over again when I connect it to the computer.
Printing via USB? Fuhgetaboutit. It never worked right. I did get Wifi working but don't trust it as much as printing from the Micro-SD.

comments.text:
Ok, it might be a good idea to define what we're talking about since many of these components have the same/similar names:
MicroSD card - Tiny SD card that actually goes into the printer
MicroSD adapter - regular SD card size, MicroSD slots in, plugs into the computer
MicroSD extender - thing you link from aliexpress, turns a microSD slot into a regular SD slot.
comments.author: Mckitrick

comments.text: So, if you plug the extender into  your computer, can you remove SD cards from said extender and the computer recognizes the SD card was removed/replaced or do you have to unplug/replug the extender from the computer?
comments.author: maxstier

comments.text: Oh I never plug the extender in the computer, the extender stays in the printer and I just move the SD card back and forth.  And I'm using an actual SD card which I believe are going to be more reliable than a MicroSD card in an adapter.  With the extender in the printer the SD card behaves exactly like the MicroSD card in the regular stock port.  If there is an SD card inserted, it will try and read the gcode files.  Once the SD card is removed from the extender it says SD card is empty.

description.text:
This is a simple remix of Adafruit's BOTW Guardian Sword, the parts here are cut to fit on smaller beds than the original, additional screw tabs were added to the new cuts so you will need to use more than their guide calls for. I have cut the decorative add ons at different positions than the sword was, this is so that they will add strength to the blade after they are glued on. Remember to print the Blade Decor twice. The blade tips were small enough for me to print in the original, so I have not included them here. If there is a need, I can cut them as well

Huge thanks to Pedro Ruiz for the original, and for making the Fusion 360 files available

Also thank you HunterOtobe for pointing out the gap on the tabs for the Blade Handle 1 part. I have reuploaded that file, along with Blade Handle 2 with the tabs repositioned to where they should be

comments.text:
Biggest thing that I can see as an issue is that the walls will become thinner. Noe and Pedro used a hack in the original to make sure that the walls printed thick enough (used a .4mm nozzle, but set it at .38 in the slicer) you may want to use the slice preview to do something similar to make sure that there aren't any gaps between wall layers
You may also want to reinforce the seams with some E6000, look for their Halo Energy Sword project for details on that
comments.author: kodiak1120

comments.text: Thanks for the reply.  My printer uses a 0.4mm nozzle, so you're saying I should set it to 0.38mm in the settings so there is a slight overlap?  I looked at the Halo Energy Sword project, but I don't understand how they used super glue and E600.  The tutorial says to glue the blades together and then apply E6000 to the inside, but I don't understand how you apply it to the inside after the blade is assembled.  I'm assuming they mean after each half is assembled, you apply a bead of E6000 to reinforce the walls.  Kind of a fillet in woodworking.  That definitely makes sense.
comments.author: Sraf

comments.text: Yeah, that's what you do, bead over the seam before the halves are attached.
comments.author: kodiak1120

comments.text: Sorry for being such a knucklehead, but why would there be gaps?
comments.author: Sraf

comments.text: Imagine that you have a distance between walls of 0.9mm, your slicer can only get 2 paths at 0.4mm through it, can can't really do anything with that remaining 0.1mm, so you get a gap. This is the same thing, but even more severe
comments.author: kodiak1120

comments.text: Makes sense.  Thanks for the explanation.  Going to start printing when I get home.  My transparent PLA filament should be arriving later today.  If it all works out, I'll definitely post some pictures.  I'm hoping the electronics will fit at 70%.

Here is a pseudosphere created with openSCAD. For a description see http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Pseudosphere.html The openSCAD code can also be used to generate pseudosphere sections. Two bowls, with pleasing curved surfaces, were formed from such sections. Stl files are: pseudosphere.stl
pseudosphere_half.stl
bowl_3.stl
bowl_4.stl OpenSCAD code is included.

The pseudosphere needs to be printed on a raft with support. My Replicator produced a nice smooth print except for a small dimple where the sphere touched the build surface.  
The other 3 files can be printed directly on the build platform.  An alternative to printing the pseudosphere is to print two half spheres and glue them together.

description.text:
Following up on my previous derivative, Niko with 25mm base, I made and painted this model by combining my own base with the Shiba model source. I think it turned out really well.

Painted with Testors enamel paint.

EDIT: Whoops! I uploaded the wrong stl file at first. The first one was my first try, which was too small. The second one, which is the one split from the base, is the one I successfully printed. I superglued the Shiba onto the base after removing all the support material, which worked very well.

Printer:

MP Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

80 microns

Infill:

~20%

Notes:

Printed with a 250 micron nozzle.

1. Remove support material.
  2. Glue (I used Gorilla Glue) the Shiba to the base.
  3. (optional) "paint" the Shiba's legs with superglue. This will make them MUCH stronger.
  4. (optional) Prime the model in white/off-white. This means you won't have to paint the underside of the Shiba. Bonus points if you printed in this color originally.
  5. Paint the model.

author: Laochri

title: Onera HOR20 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (28.25g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
Notice: This airfoil is pretty beefy. I had to sand down the final print pretty well, to capture all the fine details of the curve.

The propeller was inspired and designed after the Onera HOR20 airfoil coordinates. Tests were peromed on the Drone Propeller Thrust Tester (all of the results can be seen below).

Part printed at slow speed, with the help of a 0.2 nozzle at 0.04mm height per layer. I cleaned the final part with the help of an X-ACTO Knife

After this, I went on and sanded it with a 400 grit sandpaper.

Here are the thrust measurements for a few voltage presets (you can also view these in the images taken during the test):

  • 1.5V => 6.04 grams
  • 2V => 11.85 grams
  • 2.5V => 20.28 grams
  • 3V => 28.25 grams

The files you can download consist of all the pictures taken during the test, with 6 text files that have all the airfoil coordinates used in the build, the STL files and the SLDPRT files. If you want to have some fun with the propeller, you should grab a 8520 coreless motor.

Use the SLDPRT extension files, just in case you wish to make your own changes to the drone propeller.

P.S. Airfoil plotted using the matplotlib library in python.

author: emanuelbucsa

description.text:
I saw a filament ring guide that was threaded for the TAZ6 here on Thingiverse and thought it was intriguing but didn't like the bends or angles the tube on my printer would need to make. Anyway I thought ok my tube flops around a lot so let me make this ring concept work for me. I made a snap in extender for the hole in the top of the printer. The loop is also a snap fit for either the factory hole or the one in the extender.

These both were designed with a flat side so they can be printed without any overhangs.

author: rahulvisva

title: Prusa i3 MK2S No Mod Cable Chain Kit - All Axis

description.text:
Want to add Cable Chains to your MK2S but don't want to modify or reprint the Rambo Case or Extruder assembly yet? Then this might just be for you...

Looking to add cable management to replace zip ties? This might also be for you...

(Regarding MK2 Support Read below)

Originally inspired by:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1725591
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2224025
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240114

I wanted to add Cable chains to my printer as the spiral wrap/filament was beginning to sag and the x/y wraps snagged on other parts causing the Axis's to skip a couple of times.
Planning/designing other mods at this point I'm not quite ready to reprint the extruder, or Rambo case, so I came up with another option... adapters.

I initially built this as a minimally intrusive mod and factored in a couple "fixes" to deal with issues in other chain kits I've read about, assembly should be straight forward, a few parts from the spare bag and a couple pieces of 1.75mm filament is all you need!
(besides the parts... they're kinda important...)

As time went on (and after tazguy79 got me inspired to finish up the Z-Axis) I've expanded it to chain all the axis which I think completes this thing, and built on the same theme with cable management ducts (moved to a new Thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2472994).

There is lots of debate on how many chain segments are needed; In the end it doesn't matter and will vary from printer to printer.
As long as the axis's move freely you have enough. I personally went with a few more than others to match the original wire length.

There are 2 versions of the chain link included, one with "ears" and one without. I found printing 16 a time eventually one clip would pop off and ruin the batch, the ears add enough bed adhesion to keep any from popping off, and it makes taking the pieces off the bed easier.

Comments greatly appreciated, let me know what you think!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15 Optimal

Infill:

5% (or more)

Notes:

All Parts printed in ColorFabb PLA/PHA, 215 1st layer, 200 remaining, 60C hotbed. You may want support on the Y-Axis part, I didn't on the part I used in assembly but it might help.
Infill varies between parts, most were printed with 5%, the clips were 100%.

Build & Assembly Notes:

General:

  • You may need to drill the holes up a size, or sand a couple of the small features to have them fit, I designed/printed everything quite tight to account for shrinkage and allow for fine tuning of the fit.
  • All parts are designed so the wires can be slid into them, there should be no need to disconnect any wiring.

  1. X-Axis:

    • The Extruder mount is inspired by Prusa's MK2S screw attachment, press the two plates on each side of the screw, then press the mount down on top. A single zip tie tensions it and holds it in place.
    • Note, you may need to file the bottom corner of the extruder mount that will be closest to the Rambo case slightly as it gets a little tight to the case at 0,0,0, you can also substitute Crunch3D's remake: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2496035 which took care of his fitment issue, I'll be incorporating his ideas back into my design the next time I get a chance to edit this part.
    • The factory filament support stays, it and the cables route almost the same way as stock, up into the chain connector and secure them with a 2nd cable tie. Its OK if it rotates a little, its designed to do that as needed at the axis limits.
    • The Rambo mount is easiest to install if you pass the wires into it first, then slid it into place on the Rambo case, put the clip in place to close up the mount, and pass a zip tie through everything (I started feeding it into the side closest to the door) out the back and zip it up which holds everything in place. Then pass the stock filament through the mount and into the original hole, the filament adds rigidity to the chain and keeps it from sagging.

  2. Y-Axis:

    • Hotbed mount... again the filament stays! its going to help keep the chain bent and keep it from rubbing on the y-axis rail. Installs just like the stock part, once the chains are clipped on they hold the two sides together.
    • For the Rambo Case mount I snipped ~30mm off the factory filament here... (almost no mod?) the filament goes into the mount with the wires then butts up against the top of the vertical section. (under revision to add a hole for it to slide into). Use the ~30mm cut piece once the mount is pressed in place to pass through the larger hole into the factory location to lock the mount on. A short piece of 1.75mm filament goes through the 2 holes in the tabs that press in to lock it in place (in one pic you can see the white filament I used).

  3. Z-Axis:

    • The Z carriage mount prints as the rest without support, the Z Rambo mount I printed with supports on due to how its oriented and to support nut peg. There is a intended small square at the tip of one clip, this is to get Slic3r to print a small pad so the tip of the clip doesn't try to start in free space.
    • Installation should be straight forward, in my case currently used 14 chain links, and 1x M3x18 screw (from spare bag) to mount the carriage support to the x-axis motors free hole.
      The rambo mount has been updated to V2, you need to a additional spare M3x18 or longer screw to install it using one of the rambo board mounting screws. V1 is a little tight and needlenose pliers may be needed to press the filament through the supports, this only fits pre April MK2S builds with the ventilated rambo case. A short piece of 1.75mm filament goes up through 2 tabs, over through the 2 horizontal ones then back down through the other 2. I used a piece of flexible filament, if you use PLA it might be easer to do with 2 pieces only in the vertical posts only.
    • Note! to get the rotation clearance needed at Z 200+ the chain link that connects to the x-axis motor support needs a slight modification to fully rotate 90deg, refer to the pictures for info, the modified is on the left (I appologize the the quality, these were some old links) basically the two corner "pockets" on the top side need to be cut back a little, I may update the mount in the future but is is a much quicker solution for this single chain.
  4. Finishing Axis (Axi? Axis's?):
    • Finally, snap in the chains, route all the wires into them and then put in all the clips.

The parts below are required to "Chain All The Things":
X-Axis:
  • 1x Rambo_X-Axis_Mount.stl
  • 1x Extruder_X-Axis_Mount.stl
    • (Alternate: Crunch3D's Remix: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2496035 )
  • 25x Chain_Link_Ear_v2.stl (or Chain_Link_v2.stl)
Y-Axis:
  • 1x Rambo_Y-Axis_Mount.stl
  • 1x Heatbed_Y-Axis_Mount.stl
  • 13x Chain_Link_Ear_v2.stl (or Chain_Link_v2.stl)
Z-Axis:
  • 1x Rambo_Z-Axis_Mount_V2.stl (Alt - only for MK2S's with the vented Rambo case V1)
  • 1x Carriage_Z-Axis_Mount.stl
  • 14x Chain_Link_Ear_v2.stl (or Chain_Link_v2.stl)

As it has has a different Rambo case the adapters don't fit...

After a few comments/message chains with others regarding fitting this on a MK2 I thought I'd share some information below. As I don't have one I'm not 100% sure on the fit but haven't heard of any issues.

Regarding the Rambo Case:

As I don't haven't designed a new Rambo case (the reason for this thing) you have a couple options...

  • You could go with Aaron Yourks MK2S kit (thing 2240114), you need only the rambo_chain_link_for_mk2s.stl from that thing for the Case's base, additionally you also need MK2S case hinges and the door which are within the MK2S upgrade files available from Prusa at http://www.prusa3d.com/prusa-i3-printable-parts/ (you'd need RAMBo_hinges.stl and RAMBo-doors.stl specifically). The reason being that the MK2 Case and MK2S case differ in how they close, they swap which side the pins are on so the MK2 door won't close on the MK2S base.
  • There is also another version of his kit for the MK2 specifically at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0jxtOw5wECc-rambo-chain-link-for-mk2-x-axis-only which "should" eliminate the need to re-print the door.

To chain those specifically you would still need my:

  • Extruder X-Axis mount Extended (to fit the case offset difference)
  • Heatbed Y-Axis Mount
  • Rambo Z-Axis Mount (this should line up from my measurements against his case backs)
  • The Carriage Z-Axis Mount

  • All the Chains...

  • Alternatively, you could print the upgrade files for the MK2S available from Prusa at http://www.prusa3d.com/prusa-i3-printable-parts/ specifically RAMBo-MK2S-upgrade_PET_8H.gcode which is just the case parts. After that, all the above pieces will fit.

v1.0 - Initial upload
v1.1 - Added "Extruder X-Axis Mount Extended" at the request of Hermy65, it should be compatible with Aaron Yourk's MK2S Rambo case.
v1.2 - Updated Extruder X-Axis Mount Extended to scale properly (was 10x intended).
v1.3 - Thanks to jltx for catching a glitch in the code, the Chain Link & Chain Link Ear STL files had a slight glitch in the first layer, its been corrected. v2 of the parts is correct.
v2.0 - Added Z-Axis chains at the request of tazguy79.
V3.0 - Added Cable Ducts...
V3.1 - Moved Cable Ducts to their own thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2472994/
V3.2 - added "new" rambo case z-mount for initial testing on post march 2017 Rambo case
V3.3 - Updated to reference Crunch3D's remixed x-axis extruder mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2496035 which increases the spacing between the mount and the RAMBo case, his parts ideas will be incorporated into the next edits.
V3.4 - Updates to a couple part names, upgrade the Rambo z-axis mount to V2 to support the new case style and screw mount.

comments.text:
Hey Bonsai-User,
Are you saying you used the old mount (V1) and now use the V2 mount and the cables are too short?
The two mounts should be the same other than the method of mounting. The Stepper motor wires are "tight" and I'm guessing between builds they could vary a little.
I've only had issues at max Z, below that there isn't a issue at least with mine, but what I did was remove two chain clips right near the carriage mount and replaced them with black elastics, that lets them stretch a little at the very top.
Extending the cables is a option if yours are tight, I haven't done it yet but plan to the next time I need to take it apart, there are also stepper motor extenders available online.

comments.text:
I think I understand what you're asking, When you're printing the x-axis rambo mount with support (i'm still trying to figure out a better way to align it) the zip tie "tunnels" through it are getting filled with support?
I'm not too familiar with ABS (only used it a little when I started) but I know it has "some" issues with bridging, if you don't need the little bit of support thats on the top of the part (that Slic3r wants to add for the clip bumps) can you print it with "Support on build plate only" enabled? that'd get rid of the support inside the zip tie tunnels.
There's no selective support within slic3r that I'm aware of unfortunately (I hope they add it someday) but when I run into "odd" situations just needing a little support and not pounds of it I'll just add it manually to the model then slice it without support.
If "support on build plate only" doesn't help, if you could let me know where you need support on that part I'd be happy to send you a stl with it built in.

comments.author: RussW

comments.text:
Good Evening Russ!
I apologize for not reading/replying sooner, Its been a day... :)
Glad to help, anything I can do I'll be happy to in order to get you the parts you need.
The parts are in a little bit of a mess at the moment and I'm working to update them all, you say you have a February MK2S? Mines a early April one and mid April was as far as I can tell when they made a change to the RAMBo case which removed the vents(louvers) and went with the solid case design.
You say you can't locate a slot or opening to insert the diagonal tab projection, can you tell me which STL you printed?
was it the Rambo_z-axis_mount.stl with the 6 pins?
If your RAMBo case doesn't have the vent's/slots its the newer version they just just recently posted the files for, I had a few back and forth comments from nuroo on the new design and pushed the "new" testing part out but never heard back from him if it fit. Based on recent comments by Sarek27 and a modified mount, you'd need instead to use the Rambo_Z-Axis_Mount_new_case_WIP.stl which is made to mount via the bolt hole instead with a longer screw from the spare parts bag.
If you'd indulge me and give me a few hours (its 2:23am here now) say 10 hrs, I'll update the parts with the latest versions, the case change threw me initially, just want to make sure I direct you to the right part for your machine, if you could provide a picture of the lower rambo case where the mount goes it'd be much easier to tell you exactly which mount you need.
Sorry again Russ for the confusion in the parts, I don't think its anything to do with age or being dense lol...
I'm getting a little dense myself at 40+... something? 42....yep... 42...
(I did the math) at 75 I hope I'll still be playing with new things lol, If my genes hold out I'll be lucky, just got a e-mail from my dad who needs me to help him align the laser cutter he just bought, he's still having fun at 80...

comments.author: nuroo

comments.text:
Sorry to hear it didn't fit properly,
I'm still looking to track down a drawing of the case back, I can't see it being that much different other than the vent slots, but I'm wondering if there are any other changes that might be causing the issues.
The wires at the top of the Z-axis are a little tight, but I haven't had any issues with the wires being too short, I wonder if it could be due to differences in wiring assembly ie. the length of the motor wires from the factory. There isn't a lot of space or extra wire length working with the factory routing to begin with, I 'm not sure with this design how/if I can get more.
I printed the WIP mount the other day and just tried it on mine and I see what I did there... I moved the mount up ~4mm to try and give a little more room for the wire and to make the nut install easier, but I didn't run interference tests in the model at that time and just noticed that it moved the mount into the 1mm interference range with the motor at 0,0,0, and at Ztop it unexpectedly made the wires a little tighter at the top ( i had to pull a clip as well).
I'm going to re-model it here and change the mount to move it back to the original location, if your interested I'll have a modified part up hopefully sometime today after I get a chance to print/install/test it properly.

Same as before, pop the screw and nut, in this case drop the nut in the retaining slot from the inside of the mount, put the screw through and tighten. I extended the screw hole all the way through so any length screw should work.

I'll have to look at that part a little closer, I'm not sure why it had issues in your case, I added a image to the "thing", I think its the 10th image, the best angle/closeup I could get of my X-Axis mount when the carriage is driven into the endstop, I've still got about 1mm clearance at that point.
I did have a issue prior to building/mounting the chains with my x-axis hitting the frame and not the endstop, in my case my x-axis limit switch had gotten pressed back a little, needed to loosen the screws and move it back to the right (from the front) and tighten the screws. Just curious if this might be contributing to your fit issue a little.
I looked at if I can cut that corner on 45deg a little, but it might make it more difficult to print as there's little material in that area for support on the build plate, I'll update the instructions to note there might be clearance issues and filing the corner slightly might be needed.

comments.text: Not sure how old your machine is, but I ran into issues with bed adhesion early on with my MK2S, here's a couple things I found that might help:
comments.author: tazguy79

comments.text: Hopefully printing them soon. Had a roll of ABS laying around for a couple months cause I ordered it with my last PLA, but was nervous to use it as people said smell was horrible, and it was hard to print. Put it in my TV cabinet with door closed and a blanket over it and turned fan on in living room and I can barely smell it. As far as being harder to print....straight up untrue...first print has perfect adhesion (cable chains without ears) and going 100x better than my PLA ones. (Blaming cheap filament for adhesion. Both the PLA and ABS I got were about 12$ from walmart online) Just wanted to find cheapest I could and see if it was good enough for my purposes. Apparently the ABS will be, but the PLA was too stringy and 0 adhesion. Only concern left is ABS shrinkage
comments.author: SoundDoc

comments.text:
I haven't printed much in ABS not due to the smell, but more due to the reported VOC's and increased particles it releases (not sure how much of a "real" concern it is vs a perceived one) as my wife is quite sensitive to dust/allergens and any ABS printing even with a fan/charcoal filter in the house triggered her issues. I also found ABS is much more sensitive to temperature changes and the mentioned shrinkage was annoying as a lot if things I print are replacement parts or have small tolerances., in that aspect I've found PLA much better, and overall for me at least its been a much easier to work with material. (plus I don't have to sit/live in the garage when I'm printing lol).
Things I'd have printed in ABS before I've switched to PETG (PET, PETT etc...), again its easier to work with than ABS imho, and doesn't shrink/warp as much.

remixed_from.title: Ikea LED mount (tweaked) for Vertex K8400

title: Ikea LedBerg clip for Vertex K8400

description.text:
As I found out the Ikea Dioder series was discontinued and I still wanted to put LED-strips in my 2nd Vertex K8400 I bought the replacement series "Ledberg" LED-strips. These need a slightly bigger clips than the Dioder series did so I remixed H60's design to fit the "Ledberg" series. Also, the "new" 2017 series has only 6 LED's per strip, these are a bit brighter than the Dioder LED's btw as can be seen the picture.

A couple of drawbacks of the Ledberg series are:

  • There are only 3 strips in a package, but, the adapter allows for the connection of 4 strips. The adapter can supply 3 watts and the light strips use 6 x 0.06 watts = 0.36 Watts, so 4 strips only use 1.44 Watts, well within the limit. I observed no temperature change in the adapter running 4 strips.
  • These LED-strips do not include the short wires to connect the strips around corners. I choose to solder wires directly to the strips, though a bit of extra work this works fine! Using a wire of 5 cm or 2 inches for the Metric impaired will do nicely.

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers

Infill:

25%

description.text:
Q1 mini is an open source quadruped robot for everyone!

Q1 mini features:

  • 8 DOF using MG90S / SG90 servo.
  • All-in-one controller board - TinyPlan V400, simple design and built-in battery.
  • Remote control the robot through the wifi.

Demo:
http://youtu.be/jOsnoSP70g8

Assembly Instructions and all file for this project:
http://q1.jasonworkshop.com

3D Printed parts

comments.text:
Hahaha, wow, supernice. I have been trying to source parts from old printers for a long time, but in my country (the Netherlands) it is nearly impossible to get materials from the dumpyard after they have been delivered.
Right now my city is wanting to be a '3D-print' city, so I am trying to find out ways of getting the city council to cooperate with me and give me more freedom to move in and out of the electronic scrapyard et cetera because I think it can be a great inspiration for kids.
I'm also working in a radial cooling fan. Now I've made one, but it's cooling too good, so I have to make it 2 pipes coming out instead of just one. Right now the pipe is blowing too much on one side of my PLA prints, and this causes it to warp a little bit on that side, while if I spread the flow of air to come from 2 sides, I can let the fan run at higher speeds, causing it to cause less frequency noise (from the PWM) and it will cool the PLA better because it cools more evenly.
It's nice to see how everyone thinks differently about parts-design. You have the fan mounted sideways, I have connected it to my vertical X-carriage as some sort of a 'backpack', that hangs on a frame. The frame is then connected with 4 tie-rips. The tie-rips go into the X-carriage and also secure the LM8UU bearings at the same time. It was important for me to add a solution that didn't require 'yet another set of bolts'.
Right now I'm working on a new direct-drive bowden extruder, but I might also go back to using a standard non-bowden direct drive because I notice that my printer doesn't print well at high-speed anyway.

title: Exversa Juno 6mm Carbon Mini Quad - No Shell

description.text:
This is a No Shell version which means you can buy the 6mm carbon frame, titanium and standoffs. You will have to print your own shell downloadable via Thingiverse.

With the design experience of the Apollo, we maintain the teardrop shape. To make sure the Juno is enclosed with the most aerodynamic shell.

The Juno is made of top grade materials. We use 6mm 3K Twill weave carbon fiber, Titanium and 3D Sintered nylon to craft an object of pure form and function.

The sleek arms insure that nearly all thrust generated by the props is 95% unobstructed, by having them at 6X10mm they still remain the mandatory stiffness.

The top plate has a built-in camera mount for both regular Go Pros as wel as RunCam sized cameras. Also it insures proper cooling without interfering the airflow. So no need for extra 3D printed mounts that often increase the weight notibly.

Get the most value for your money and buy the Juno together with the EX-Foot 2207 2600KV motor to get the most out of the Juno's aerodynamic shapes! (www.miniquadtestbench.com/xfoot-2207-2600kv.html)

Base: 220 - 250

title: Tri-Nut Spinner USA
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Fun spinner with a printed bearing.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print two of the Grip Half piece. Join the two halves with a short length of filament (about 4 mm) for alignment. Scrape off any excess plastic and sand the grips and bearing race until it spins freely. Make permanent with a small amount of super glue at the center, not enough to flow to the bearing race.

Jam 1/2" nuts into the holes and glue if necessary.

Spin, spin, spin!

NOTE: I will put up an M10 nut version soon. Metric prices are outrageous here so I only bought 3 metric nuts for sizing.

This is a simple yet very functional hand crank for the back of a dual shaft NEMA23 8mm stepper motor.

The exact motor I used is here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/322128751249

You will also need a M3 socket head screw about 20-25mm long. I used a 30mm partial thread type and then cut the threaded section shorter so the handle is on the non threaded smooth portion. But I am pretty sure it will work just fine if you used it with a fully threaded 20mm long screw.

description.text:
After upgrading my UM2-switch to a dual color printer, it was time to print something.
So I decided to print the name of my new born son.

Since I could not find duplo characters like this, the goals is to create a complete duplo compatible dual color ABC.. (Ready: 20 out of 26.) But I'm in no rush at all. ;)

When I have some spare time left, I'm willing to generate that one missing character first.. If you find issue's, please let me know, I'll try to improve it.

title: Builder BigBuilder (Original) enhanced fan duct replacement

description.text:
This is the story of a 3000€ printer. https://www.3dhubs.com/3d-printers/big-builder-dual-feed-extruder

It has great framing, great rods, great extruders, great volume, great precision, great mixing solutions, and then...

1 ) An optional, not so great hot bed whitout sensor, allright.
2) Only ONE duct on ONE side of the head for a printer of THAT size? No possible upgrades? Years after release?

Happy that I bought it second hand at less that half the price, else, I would be so pissed.

It is not passing the Marvin test. Can you imagine?

So here it is, this is the first working version of this little project to replace the original duct (keeping the same fan, at the same position) with one doing a better job. Printing marvin with it was a success, including the hook. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215703

Feel free to improve it, there must be room left for it. Source file included.

UPDATE

After two days, I can already say: Avoid PLA unless your duct fan is always on, else, above 200° it will bend down to the plate in +- 40 mins. ABS is the way to go (if not obvious...). Please write down your comments if you print and test it, thanks!

remixed_from.author: DOHCDragon
remixed_from.title: RC Tiger 1 Tank Computer Case - Quakecon 2014 Winner

description.text:
16.Dec.2017 Update: updated Arduino Code to have soft acceleration and breaking.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WUGgQdvLi4

This is a remix of DOHCDragon's Tiger 1 PC Case.
I redesigned it to have a Suspension, an PC inside wasnt the plan for me. I also made some changes in the original Parts because of some wrong distances. The Parts wasn managed at all so i sort them a bit..

Parts I changed and created: Lower Frame, Upper Frame, Suspension Axle, Suspension Lever left and right, Outside axle, Inside Wheel, Transmission, Turret Front, Turret Base. Maybe thats not all.
I just printed the original Files and made changes in the Design after i encountered problems or to make asseambly easier. This means the Design are based on my building experience and the parts are not printed this way at my tank..
The axle is designet for a tight fit and there are missing holes in the Frame. Use a 5 and 5,5 mm Drill to make the holes and wheel work nice.

Its a bit of a pain to find out how to build this. Just a few tipps how to get on.
First: Dont glue the parts on after you print it. Just print and fit ALL parts that belong together or you get problems afterwards.
Second: Just try things out.
I printed all parts in differen brands of PLA. The Frame got 60% infill, the Suspension 100% and the details and accessories 20-30%, wheels 25-35%. The Parts was friction welded togehter, I think this looks a bit more like a real tanks was made. At some parts I used superglue. I spray painted it afterwards to get the same color on all Parts.
Gears of the Transmission was printed with Nylon, maybe PLA would work too.
I used around 4kg PLA for the Tank.
7x19mm Springs should work for the Suspension.
The Turret is mountet on an old CD-Tray, so you have tomake this yourself.
For canon elevation i used a MG996R Servo. For driving i used 2 old long-type airsoft motors.
This all is controlled with my Smartphone and the Bluetooth RC App. The Smartphone connects to the HC-05 bluetooth Module.
An Arduino UNO with Dual Monster Moto Shield (VNH2SP30) was used to control the motors.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20-100%

Exactly these: https://www.federnshop.com/de/produkte/druckfedern/d-065.html , mayby you find similar springs.

comments.text: I'm like half way done with the tank. I could finish it already but was too busy IRL. One question: How did you secured the tracks on both sides of the turret? Did you glued them on or is it force fit?
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text: It looks like a force fight as the lower bracket has a little peg.
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text: Hi.
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text: Ok I solved the problem. I just had to switch TX and RX on the bluetooth module. The next issue I need to solve is why does the turret motor turn on when I try to move forward. I think it's the app and I probably need to reconfigure all controls according to the arudino schematic that you provided. Will report how it goes tomorrow. :)
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text: I have some questions:
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text:
• The left one is like you guess it, a voltage regulator the get 6 to 7 Volts for the Servo. But its like a shit setup because if i set the Voltage higher than 6V the Servo freaks out for no reason. maybe something is broken there. The right one is the motordriver (L298N) for the DC worm gear Motor to rotate the turret.
  • I use a 3S Lipo 1500mah 25C, higher capacity would be better.
  • Yes the VNH2SP30 Shield is mounted on my arduino uno. The bluetooth just connects to the RX and TX pins both sides.
  • The turret (CD tray motor) is attatched to the top hull plate and sticks all the way up. The Gear is just sitting loose on the shaft (cant get away). The motorshaft has a D-shape. I just get the perfect fit with a bit of paper and Superglue. The servo cable just sticks through the plates, so i cant rotate 360°. I added two pics.
    Im also new to the arduino stuff, this is why my code is pretty simple. The is a great arduino uno simulator for testing out there ;)
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text:
Oh I see. Let me guess:
To lift the gun up and down you used a piece of "steel" wire that you fixed on the servo arm and the little hole in front of the turret face. And the thing above the servo is a rubber band to soften the up and down movement?
comments.author: Rammelhorst

comments.text: Exactly.
comments.author: BoskoSLO

comments.text: I'm about to print some parts for the suspension. I don't quite get it how are the wheels build. Are the outside road wheels glued together? (2 pieces) and is there a spacer on both halves glued inside so the inside wheel lever can fit? And is the "outside wheel lever" used with the combination of the two road wheels separated with the outside axle? I hope you understand what I mean. if not I can explain my self better. Thank you in advance.
comments.author: Rammelhorst

comments.text: There are two axle types, one has the spacer for the inside roadwheel. Yes, just use a outside wheels on each side of the outside axle. Glue or weld them them together and then use the outside lever(without spacer). Its just that easy.

title: Alu profile chain support brackets (MPCNC v525 compatible, alu profile 15x20x1.5mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Info:

This bracket/support set is for alu profile 15x20x1.5mm (H x W x Thichness) and Mostly Printed CNC v 525 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533). One support has a link to this cable chain http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1824144.

Remark:

See attached STL files and decide which way you want to mount L-shaped alu profile and which element hast to be with chain link. If provided STL's are in wrong directions simply mirror them accordingly to your needs in your slicing software before printing.

Further info:

Ideas roughly taken from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:843399. Support for alu profile was too low for my MPCNC v525 and alu profile interfered with one of the central carriage elements. Maybe it was for older version of mpcnc.

I made brackets/supports taller, screw holes are not round but "slots" with possibility to set the alu profile at desired high.

Works with:

  1. "Mostly Printed CNC 525" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533
  2. "Print in place cable chain! (MPCNC compatible)" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1824144
    OR (untested, should fit nicely)
  3. cable chain from "Replicator 1 X-Axis Cable Chain" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119814
  4. Chain_Guide_holder_Top_Z.stl from "Brackets for Drag chain" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:843399

description.text:
Dr. Jones. Again we see there is nothing you can possess which I cannot spend months obsessively recreating in plastic filament.

This has been an extremely time consuming project. Tried to make this as accurate as possible using predominantly primary source reference. In the process of sanding and finishing it now but figured there's no reason I shouldn't make this available in the mean time. Will update photos as I work. Enjoy.

Update STL at approximately the correct size has now been added - 16 June 2017
Update New cover pic. Nearly finished sanding the model - 19 June 2017
Update New cover pic. Masked the eyes and sprayed gold - 7 July 2017
Update New cover pic. Finished gold leaf - 2 August 2017

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

If you split this model in half down the centre then lay it down; it will print without supports. If you print the single model upright then you will need to turn supports on.

Finished model should be 7 3/4"-8" (190-200mm) in height. Scale accordingly.

I printed my idol in quarters without support I like Gooooooooold

I experimented with a number of different gold finishes. Plasticote gold spray paint isn't bad, about the same end result as rub'n'buff but easier to apply. I found the closest you can get to the vac-metalised finish of the original is a mirrored faux gold leaf. I applied this over a coat of the spray gold so any gaps in the application weren't so noticeable.

My gold tests. Left to right: Rub'n'buff Antique Gold, Plasticote Gold Spray, Liquid Leaf, Mirror Leaf

I spent a lot of time poly modelling this using photos of the Propstore idol as reference, along with screenshots from the movie. Where the detail was unclear I referred to images of the Gobler idol which I'm lead to believe is a casting of an original.

The biggest challenge was the hair. I tried a number of methods of modelling this but eventually turned to displacement mapping to achieve the required effect.

title: SELFIE-STIK
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This 'Selfie-Stik' is completely 3D printed in multiple parts. It's easy to assemble, folds away to a compact size that fits in the palm of your hand but extends out to approx. 37.5cm in length. Use in conjunction with the self timer function included on almost all mobile phones (i.e. does not include a mechanism to push the button to take a photo)

This is a practical low cost way of having a compact, lightweight selfie stick on hand when you need it... and it works great if well printed and assembled. However, to achieve a great result, you need a well set up / accurate machine, precise slicing app and to use high infill to make it strong.

When you've printed and assembled your Selfie-Stik insert your phone and tighten the bolt against it with a moderate pressure (but not enough to damage the phone). This should hold your phone securely in place... then set your phones self timer and start taking selfies.

Please note that the angles designed into the self stick make it appear to bend backwards slightly plus the phone mount is also angled backwards. This is necessary to ensure the handle is out of the image area so is not visible in your selfies.

As a precaution, start by printing a couple of the smaller parts and pins first and check they fit together well, they rotate, the threads are clean / precise so they screw in as required and can be lightly tightened. Assuming all is okay continue to print the remaining parts and finish your assembly.

At first use the Selfie-Stik may seem quite flexible and lacking in strength. However, PLA is very brittle and strong so, unless you exert excessive pressure on it, a well printed Selfie-Stik with high infill applied should do a great job.

Please refer to the print settings provide and images for additional information. If you print your own Selfie-Stik please post images for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard

Infill:

PLA / 50% or more infill / 2 shells

Notes:

The parts are all easy prints on an accurate well set up machine with a precisely sliced file. Use high infill to ensure your finished product is strong and able to safely withstand the weight of your phone.

Print one of each part with the exception of the pins. You need to print 5 pins in total.

A small amount of assembly required... it's easy!

Refer to the images for assembly instructions.

Well printed parts should slide / screw together easily. The pins can be glued in place if you want to ensure your Selfie-Stik never comes apart. Applying a light lubricant to the moving surfaces will help make the folding action easy and smooth.

A small amount of force should be necessary to clip the Selfie-Stik closed. Refer to he images for details.

Do not over tighten the pins or you risk wrecking the printed threads... it is just plastic!

Once your Selfie -Stik has been assembled insert your phone and gently tighten the bolt against it until it is securely held in place. Use with the self timer on your phone.

description.text:
This is a coffee tamper for handpresso coffee machines
It fits the coffee pods

LMU88 Replacement Bearing with multi-contact & multi-direction surfaces. No play in any direction and the design is scalable to suit other shaft diameters.

I have only printed it in PLA but PLA is not the best wear material. Probably best in ABS or PETG.

Internal diameter is designed size on size for an 8mm (7.95mm measured) ground rod so after shrinkage there is a slight interference hence the hollow walls for the 'give' and preload.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 or 0.05 or 0.2 if you want

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Nothing out of the ordinary, most print setting should work for this design
No overhangs so no support :)
No post required Internals Slice Slice Slice Final Print :) Internal Rifles

comments.text:
The run of the mill bearings tend to have a 'rattle' as the bearing balls move around at specific stepper frequencies. A typical LMU88 has only 4 directional bearing rows. The more expensive ones push that to 8 directions. I haven't tried the more expensive ones but assume they would still have some degree of vibration at certain frequencies.
I like this idea particularly because there is plastic elastic deformation therefore making a more rigid bearing. Yet to be proven :)

Bonus: Did you know you can skate on this sculpture in Tony Hawk Underground 2?

author: Marklochrie

title: Gemstock Delta Printer (Rosstock Mini - Mini Kossel combination)

description.text:
Hello everyone!

As promised I have now uploaded all the parts that are finished so far. Mind you, this is a work in progress, so I will be adding and subtracting as needed.

This project is intended to be a full delta printer design, with lots of room to upgrade, or deviate from bed-size.

The idea came forth of not having all the parts needed to build a Rosstock Mini. All the vertical items (smooth rods and bearings to roll over them) were available but the horizontal plates were not. Therefor I came up with the idea to use some other items I had laying around from building another printer. For the horizontal bars I have used a similar setup as the Kossel Mini. Misumi Bars / extrusions.

Short bill of material:
6x Smooth rods of 10mm and any length you want (75cm is what i used)
6x 20x40 extrusion of any length (about 20+cm is what I have used)
36x 623zz bearings (linear slider, custom design!)
Bunch of M3 & M5 screws

Many items are dependent on the sizes you choose above. Belts, bed size, carbon rods, etc. So I will be working on a design that will be a guideline with some more defined items and lengths.

Many parts I have gotten from older projects, but a printer like this can easily be below 300 euros if you are willing to buy some chinese parts.

Hope you will find this a nice design, as I have had lots of printing fun with it already!

Stefan

title: 10oz Caulk Tube Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There's a few of these I've seen on here, all of them seemed to not fit or grip well. It took a few experiments, but this one seems to work well for me. Its fit snugly, and held, on all the 10oz caulk tubes I've tried it on.

You'll need to rotate it to print, as Fusion 360 leaves things on their side.

Nothing special about printing it. If you don't have good bed adhesion you may need rafts or something, but on my printer, with a PEI surface, it printed without them.

author: jasonfr

description.text:
I updated the original design by rcexplorer for 12.7mm square (close to 1/2" square) wood boom/arms available in US. The notch to hold the arms in place does not work, so I removed it from my previous version. The large surface area seems to hold the arms in place due to friction.
The added comments will help you to modify the OpenScad file. Added APM 2.5 mount holes. I am planning to add counter sink holes for APM 2.5 mount points.
  • Edit the OpenScad file to change the width of the wood boom/arm you plan to use. Export STL file.
  • Print 2 of this part. Use them for top and bottom.
  • Follow the build instructions to make your own tri-copter.
    Sample instructions link: http://rcexplorer.se/projects/2011/09/the-tricopter-v2-5/

NOTE: This is a work in progress. I updated the original design by rcexplorer for 12.7mm square (close to 1/2" square) wood boom/arms available in US. The notch has been removed from the design as it does not seem to work. The extra surface area seems sufficient to hold the arms in place.
The added comments will help you to modify the OpenScad file. Added APM 2.5 mount holes.
  • Edit the OpenScad file to change the width of the wood boom/arm you plan to use. Export STL file.
  • Print 2 of this part. Use them for top and bottom.
  • Follow the build instructions to make your own tri-copter.
    Sample instructions link: http://rcexplorer.se/projects/2011/09/the-tricopter-v2-5/

description.text:
600 mm radius curve track for 45mm gauge tracks, common used in Garden railways (16mm and LGB scale).
There are track holders for printed sleepers och wooden sleepers.
The STL files is for a complete track, track you assemble by your self and a complete track for dual extruder printers.
You must print 6 tracks for 90 degrees curve.

Notes:

I Have not printed this track, but most parts is from 765 radius tracks, so i can't se any problems to print this track.
It should be easy to print this track, and you only need support on the complete tracks.
All STL files has been tested in Netfabb.
All STL-files named "dual" are for dual extruder print.
I have printed my tracks with PLA at 0.3mm layer height and 30-50% infill. (30% is enough, 50% is on the safe side)

description.text:
THIS DESIGN IS OBSOLETE! Please see the newest universal design here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1185076 This is filament spool roller that can accomodate 1kg spools from both MakerBot and DF Robot. The roller uses a couple of patio door ball bearings that you can get from Home Depot for $13. The bearings are notched, which cradles the rim of the spool while allowing it to easily turn. The base of the roller has two slots that allow you to adjust the width of the roller from 65mm to 75mm, so any spool that has a width in that range will work. Check out the video to get some more details, and you can find a list of parts in the instructions.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXcBH2-0TiE&feature=youtu.be

comments.text: I'll upload a DWG tonight when I get home from work. As for the M3s not fitting in the hole, that has to do with something called arc compensation. I had to perform some calibration work to get my printer to make accurate hole diameters. That calibration is designed into this part, but it is for a MakerBot Replicator 2 w/ MakerWare. I'm assuming that you are using different hardware/software/slicer, since the calibration is off on your prints. I had posted my calibration process and findings a while back here on Thingiverse... you can check out all the details at this link (including what arc compensation is in the comments section): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231984

comments.text:
Nice. I will definitely print this bike.
I have been working out a technique for signs that I think may help you. The idea is to print on glass and the multi-color layer is applied first at 0.1mm height, and adjust the printer to over-extrude. Then print the rest of the part starting at 0.3mm height. The background (black in this case) will fill in all areas around the first layer and "embed" the first layer into the part. And since you are printing on a glass bed, the end result is smooth and shinny. BTW, the first layer print needs to be mirrored.
Here is a close up of one of my first attempts. http://imgur.com/a/CdNRC

description.text:
How can the everyday life of wheelchair users be facilitated and enriched? A team of wheelchair users, technicians and designers has worked together on need analysis, idea development, prototyping and testing for solutions for wheelchair add ons. Not only the usability, but also the aesthetic side was taken into account: "We want the wheelchair not to look like old school medical equipment and but to look cool and contemporary" says Raul Krauthausen a project participant. The lighting set open°lights is one of our designs that we developed and improved with several testing rounds. There are two common shapes that we call the I and the O. The I is used for front lights and the floor light. The O is used for a backlighting. The interface of the lights is easy to handle.

With the help of open source instructions and maker technologies in Fab Labs our products can be build and customized by the users.
To get started please download the Thing Files and open the Open Lights DIY Manual.

The "Made for my Wheelchair" project is funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research. Project partners are Makea Industries GmbH, beable e. V. the Otto Bock Mobility Solutions GmbH and the Sozialhelden e.V ..

Visit http://www.madeformywheelchair.de/ and learn more about the project.

I have now re-designed all of the controller mounts. Each one console now has their own unique logo but each of the stands is now similar in shape and size! No longer will the Xbox Mount look so out of place next to the Nintendo Switch Mount or PS4 Mount. Links to the other stands are below as well; pick up one for each of your controllers!

description.text:
A very simple tag to put on your keyring and use in place of a £1 coin in a shopping trolley.

Definitely works at Asda, and I think Aldi and Tesco too - it's £1 sized so should work in anything.

There's a bunch of these on Thingiverse that are designed to twist and pull out - that feel's kinda immoral to me (if you're using it to steal trolleys) so I designed this instead.

I've also included the Cura project files for printing 1 or 3 on the Ultimaker 2 I printed it on.

remix of the openforge ruined tiles. I made it thin so you can use this pieces for modeling the miniature base.

Vacuum attachment for a DW660 cutter.  The vacuum attachment side is for a Fein vacuum hose ( the female part of this printed part is 1.35").  
The part is shown here on a modified Shapeoko 1.  
I have been using it with EPS foam, which produces very light dust.  I have not yet verified its pickup with other materials (most likely will not pick up metal chips).

Print the vacuum duct with support, it takes a bit of effort to clear it out, but I believe it is necessary.  
The clip print holds the vacuum duct on, hooking onto the groove that the router foot attachment normally attaches too.  Please take notice of the anti rotation stop in the groove, as the clip will not work if it is inline with the stop.
